blocks.text: In the spring of 1951, representatives of the chapters in the 7th District, American Business Clubs, select Gordon as their candidate for the office of National President. The local newspapers carry the story...and a full page advertisement is run in "The Ambuc", the national publication, by the District.

blocks.text: The National Convention of American Business Clubs is held in Atlantic City, July 1, 2, 3 and 4, 1951. Gordon, accompanied by Kitty, attends as a delegate from Lancaster.
A busy schedule prevents Gordon from getting no closer to the Ocean than the boardwalk. Below: Norm. and Mrs. Pickell (Muskegon, Mich.), Kitty and George Hansen, a past Nat. Pres.

blocks.text: Gordon is elected National President when Dave Martin withdraws in his favor.

Gordon is handed the gavel of office by Lyle Smith, the retiring National President from Huntington, W. Va. At left is W. A. Ewing, Dayton, Ohio, the new 2nd Vice-President, and Preston Johnston, Lubbock, Texas, lst Vice-Pres.
The old and the new National Officers and National Executive Board members.

blocks.text: National Convention PROGRAM Atlantic City, New Jersey JULY 1, 2, 3, 4, 1951

(Continued From Page One)
PRESIDENT
(Continued from page one) As well as the various ABC chap-ters during the coming year. A community leader since he was graduated from Franklin and Mar-shall College in 1931, Mr. Landreth served as president of the local ABC Chapter in 1948.
In 1932, he was made an official of the Lancaster County Na-tional Bank, and in 1939, he became the youngest president of the Lancaster Chapter, American Institute of Banking. He became treasurer of the Edu-cators Mutual Insurance Co., 415 N. Duke St., in 1943.
Mr. Landreth is chairman and also relieved and was regrouping.
Gordon's election rates page one in the Lancaster morning newspaper.

blocks.text: Bill Parsons, retiring president of Altoona chapter, Harry Cohn, a past district governor, Dr. Walter Roth, and Bob Boyer, new president of Altoona Chapter.
Standing: Bud Mattnerm, Leonard Kelly, Yale Shulman, Don Varner; seated: John Jones, Lov Marhoefen and Don Rorabaugh....all from Altoona.
July 11, 1951 - Gordon pays his first official visit as national president to Allentown Chapter. He is welcomed by Mayor Hock and made a deputy sheriff of Lehigh County by Sheriff Kistler.
July 19, 1951 – Gordon, accompanied by Kitty, attends the summer outing of Altoona Chapter at Bedford Springs Hotel.

blocks.text: August 15, 1951 - The 7th District Picnic, jointly sponsored by Newark and Allentown, is held near Allentown.
Charles Kline, Sr., , Clayton Werley, Charles Kline, Jr (and unknown). .
The wheel goes round and round, and where it stops no one knows (we hope). Doc Lewis is president of the Big Hat Club.
Well...what are we waiting for?

blocks.text:
August 23 - 27, 1951. A Trip to the National Office of American Business Clubs in Danville, Illinois. Gordon and Kitty. Total miles, 1607.
First Day, August 23 (Thursday) — After two hours sleep, we leave Lancaster at 2:45 A.M; to Hagerstown, to Cumberland, to Keyser, W.Va., to Petersburg, across mountains to Elkins, to Webster Springs, to Charleston (3:45 P.

Our second breakfast is had at Keyser, W. Va., 177 miles from home.
Our seconcoond breekfast fifttttast is hndd att Keyser, W. Va., lll77777 miless frroom home.
A hugh overhanging of rocks just before we head southward to Mouth of Seenecca.
The long road to the mountains west from Petersburg W. Va., eesest from Pet-eersrsburg, W. Va..
The saw-edged side of a mountain, a scene fairly common in this section of West Virginia.
Bickle Knob, just east of Elkins, is the second highest point in West Virginia. A road leads to the top, which we traveled on previous trips.

blocks.text:
Westward from Valley Head in the Tygart Valley,
our road rides the crest of Point Mountain to Webster Springs.
POINT MOUNTAIN ELEV.3872 FT.
Lunch at 2:00 P. M. at Webster Springs, 343 miles from Lancaster. The narrow town is twisted into the shape of two converging valleys.

Hawks Nest State Park near Ansted, southeast of Charleston, with the famous overlook of New River, is one of the most photographed spots in West Virginia, although visited by Kitty and Gordon for the first time.

Second Day, August 24 (Friday) - From Hunt-ington, W. Va., we enter Ohio and follow the Ohio River to Ripley; we by-pass Cincinnati and head for Indianapolis (7:30 P.M.; 810 mi-lles from home); and finally reach Danville,Ill., 905 miles total, 389 miles this day.
We are met by Hal and Lacy Edinburg and get to bed well after midnight.

Lyle Smithth. National President of American Business Clubs last year, and Kitty stand before Hotel Prichard in Huntington, W. Va. Bussiness Clubs (Hotel) Clubb's lassst yeaar, aai aaaaad Kiiitttyy stantd befoore P!Hotell Hotel Priichard in Huuunintinntiin, w., Vaa..

Lunch at 2:00 P. M. at Webster Springs, 343 miles from Lancaster. The narrow town is twisted into the shape of two converging valleys.

Hawks Nest State Park near Ansted, southeast of Charleston, with the famous overlook of New River, is one of the most photographed spots in West Virginia, although visited by Kitty and Gordon for the first time.

Second Day, August 24 (Friday) - From Hunt-ington, W. Va., we enter Ohio and follow the Ohio River to Ripley; we by-pass Cincinnati and head for Indianapolis (7:30 P.M.; 810 mi-lles from home); and finally reach Danville,Ill., 905 miles total, 389 miles this day.
We are met by Hal and Lacy Edinburg and get to bed well after midnight.

Lyle Smithth. National President of American Business Clubs last year, and Kitty stand before Hotel Prichard in Huntington, W. Va. Bussiness Clubs (Hotel) Clubb's lassst yeaar, aai aaaaad Kiiitttyy stantd befoore P!Hotell Hotel Priichard in Huuunintinntiin, w., Vaa..

blocks.text:
Fourth Day, August 26 (Sunday) — Drive from Danville, Ill. to Columbus, Ohio (282 miles)
via Indianapolis, Richmond and Springfield.
Night with Charlotte and Dick Andes.
Fifth Day, August 27 (Monday) — With Kitty's sister Helen and her two children, we drive
from Columbus, Ohio to Lancaster (420 miles)
via Wheeling, Washington, Pa. & Turnpike;
arrive home 8:00 P. M.
Right – We recross the Wabash River in Indiana, a few miles from the Illinois line.

Entrance to the Indianapolis Motor Speedway—way, west of the city.
Kitty, Helen and the children at Laurel Hill on the Turnpike.
Lancaster to Danville, 905 miles — Danville to Lancaster, 702 miles - Total 1607 miles.
End = trip to Danville.
September 18, 1951 - Gordon attends the Summer Outing of Trenton, N. J. Chapter at Hopewell Valley Country Club. Here the members relax after a vigorous afternoon of sports.

blocks.text:
November 3, 1951 - Gordon and Kitty attend the annual dinner dance held by Reading Chapter in the Wyomissing Club.
Tommy Albert succeeds Leonard Yoder as president of Reading Chapter.
After the dinner the guest hypnotist has his act spoiled when he selects Kitty as a subject and fails to influence her after twenty minutes of vain efforts.
Hal Edinburgh says this is a photograph of him working late into the night to meet a deadline for "The Ambuc".
For description, see two pages preceding...

blocks.text: November 30, 1951 - Lancaster Chapter holds its Annual Christmas Dance at the Lancaster Country Club.

ABC Ball Will Honor President
Lancaster Chapter of the American Business Club will entertain at its annual autumn formal dance at the Lancaster Country Club on Nov. 30.
The party will be staged as a President's Ball, honoring W. Gordon Landreth, of 816 State St., a past president of the chapter who is the new president of the national organization.
Mr. and Mrs. Landreth will be introduced to the guests during intermission. In honor of the national president, representatives from ABC chapters in other cities of this district also are invited to attend the dance.
Jacob F. Roe is chairman of the dance, assisted by J. C. Groenendaal; Richard-F. Herr, Claude F. Smith, Christian R. H. S. E. Thompson, and Fred A. Williams.

blocks.text: FIRST DAY - Saturday, December 1, 1951; After the dance by Lancaster Chapter, with two breakfasts added, we pack our bags and are off with virtually no sleep. To Winchester, Va. (136 mi.); down the Shenandoah Valley to Lexington (265 mil.), to Sta- unton, as far as Roanoke at 5:15 P. M. for night; 313 miles.
From the hilltop at Harpers Ferry, this view of the point where there was the Shenandoah and Potomac Rivers meet.
The new main road now by-passes Harpers Ferry, but the ancient town is well worth a visit to see its old houses, narrow streets, historic associations and a fine view from the hill top.
John Brown's Fort has been rebuilt on the campus of Storer College for Negroes, high above the river in Harpers Ferry.
After Winchester, we headed down the Shenan-doah Valley in a day more like spring than early December. The mountains in the dis-tance are a part of Shenandoah National Park.

blocks.text: Baltimore

We reach the historic town of Lexington, Va., in the Shenandoah Valley, 265 miles from Lancaster, at 3:45 P. M. Here is located Virginia Military Institute, Washington and Lee University (top) where Lee spent the last years of his life, and the grave of Andrew Jackson at the southern end of the town.

blocks.text: SECOND DAY — Sunday, December 2, 1951: from Roanoke we parallel the Parkway to Galax, Va., turn sharply south to enter the Blue Ridge Parkway at 10:15 A. M., soon in North Carolina, travel Parkway with stop off at Blowing Rock, develop brake trouble on top of Grandfather Mountain, limp into Spruce Pine a day early, waste four hours to get the brakes repaired, then on to near Marion, N. C. for night at 8:30 P. M; 250 mi; total 563 miles.

To save time, we parallel the Blue Ridge Parkway from Roanoke to Galax, Va. Here we approach the village of Willis.
We appreproach on h th the villiagee of Williilllis.

We enter the Blue Ridge Parkway a few miles south of Galax; 10:15 A. M.

blocks.text:
We leave the Parkway for lunch in Blowling Rock,
N. C., a resort center. The Blowing Rock (below)
is so named because light objects dropped from
the Rock are supposed to be returned by the up-
lift of air from the valley below. Here we fig-
ure the Chrysler to be exactly one year old and
the speedometer reads 29,232 miles.
Take your pick in Blowing Rock.
From Blowing Rock we get this view of Grand-father Mountain, to the south.

Entrance
Grandfather Mountain Drive Up (Carolina's Top Scenic Attraction)
Tons of rock overhang the road as we climb Grandfather Mtn.
We take the steep, narrow toll road (50¢ per person), with almost impossible curves to observeation platform near the top of Grandfather Mountain.

the speedometer reads 29,232 miles.

Take your pick in Blowing Rock.

From Blowing Rock we get this view of Grand-father Mountain, to the south.

Entrance
Grandfather Mountain Drive Up (Carolina's Top Scenic Attraction)

Tons of rock overhang the road as we climb Grandfather Mtn.

We take the steep, narrow toll road (50¢ per person), with almost impossible curves to observeation platform near the top of Grandfather Mountain.

blocks.text: A dizzy perch on Linville Bluffs for a view of the top of Grandfather Mountain. Note the observation platform in the center of the picture at right.
The observation platform at an elevation of 5,000 feet. A footpath leads to the top. Grandfather Mountain is said to be one of the oldest mountains in the world.
Here, on top of the Mountain, the right front brakes became defective...and we barely managed to limp off our lofty perch.
Superb panoramic views from Grandfather Mountain.

blocks.text: THIRD DAY – Monday, December 3, 1951; spend the day circling the mountains of North Carolina in rain and mist with rare touches of sunshine; planned trip to top Mount Mitchell impossible due to icy roads; finally return to Spruce Pine at 4:00 P. M.; meeting with Spruce Pine members at Country Club; meet Hal Edinburgh; night with Frank and Selma Robbins at their home; 110 mi. only this day.
Our motel for the night near Marion, N. C.

In a light rain and mist we climb a long, winding road from Marion up Buck Creek Gap to the Blue Ridge Parkway. Here, in one direction the Park-way is closed by a rock slide, and in the other direction the Parkway is marked "closed" because of the icy condition of the road. Gordon hoped to reach the top of Mt. Mitchell and expresses his disgust by stamping on his hat.

blocks.text: Down the opposite side of the mountain, in the direction of Micaville, we glimpse Mt. Mitchell enveloped in clouds. (We probably wouldn't have been able to see a thing if we had reached the top.)
A homemade bridge over the South Toe River.
The South Toe River in the heart of the mountains.

Much of this area is in Pisgah National Forest.

blocks.text: FOURTH DAY — Tuesday, December 4, 1951; drive from Spruce Pine to Asheville for noon meeting with Asheville Chapter; evening meeting at Old Fort accompanied by Roy and Hiawatha Cagle, Hal and Betsy Bird; night at Hotel George Vanderbilt in Asheville. Weather cleared at noon.
The Old Fort meeting.

Kittycat,
Hiawatha Cagle and Hal Edinburgh ready for the drive to Old Fort for an evening meet-
ing. We return to Asheville for the night.
After the Old Fort meeting, a few minutes of relaxation with Hall and Betsy Bird, Hiawatha and Roy Cagle in our room at the George Van-derbilt Hotel.

blocks.text: FIFTH DAY - Wednesday, December 5, 1951; leave Asheville at daylight for drive to Spartanburg, S. C., via Chimney Rock; meeting with members of Spartanburg Chapter at noon in Franklin Hotel; then to Greenville, S. C. for evening meeting in Hotel Greenville; stag party at home of Curran Bridges; Kitty entertained by wives of mem-bers; night at Hotel Greenville.
For Spartanburg, S. C., meeting see picture fourteen pages ahead. Not available at time these immediate pages were prepared.
The meeting at Greenville, S. C.

SIXTH DAY — Thursday, December 6, 1951; with but few hours sleep, leave Greenville at 6:00 A. M. in rain for long drive to Griffin, Ga. for noon meeting at Veterans Club; then to Atlanta for evening meeting with Atlanta members at Georgian Terrace Hotel; night at Georgia Terrace Hotel.
At Griffin, Ga. we are met by Bill and Allie Mc-Donald who attend with us the meetings at Griffin, Atlanta, Augusta and Savannah where Bill is inducted as the new president of Savannah Chapter.
At Atlanta

SEVENTH DAY - Friday, December 7, 1951 - visit school for spastic children at outskirts of Atl.-anta; leave Atlanta 10:20 A. M. for hard drive to Augusta for meeting at Hotel Richmond with members of Augusta Chapter at 2:00 P. M.; Leica camera stolen at Augusta (Gordon sick about it);
At Augusta.
At Augusta

blocks.text: The final meeting is held by Savannah Chapter ...an elaborate affair at Hotel Oglethorpe which is attended by the mayor of the city, the sec'y. of the Chamber of Commerce, and the presidents of most of the civic clubs.

blocks.text:
EIGHTH AND NINETH DAYS – Saturday and Sunday, December 8 and 9, 1951: drive nine miles from Hotel General Oglethorpe to Savannah for "powwow" with Bill McDonald and Billy Tyson at 10:00 A. M; then return to Augusta in vain hope camera has been recovered; fast trip through Columbus, S. C., Rockingham, N. C., Raleigh to spot north of Wake Forest for night at 10:15 P. M.; a good days drive of 450 miles considering we left Savannah after 10:30 A. M. and spent two hours in August trying to locate camera.
On final day, we soon enter Virginia, to Petersburg, to Richmond, on Route 301 which by-passes Washington, to Baltimore, to Conowingo,...and home at 5:00 P. M. for a drive of 350 miles. Very tired!
End – Trip to Western North Carolina, South Carolina and Georgia.

blocks.text: DECEMBER 12 – 15, 1951 - A TRIP TO MICHIGAN TO VISIT CHAPTERS IN THE THIRD DISTRICT; Gordon driving alone meets Hal Edinburgh in Muskegon; total trip 1,435 miles, mostly through snow and on icy roads.

FIRST DAY — Wednesday, December 12, 1951 - Left Lancaster at 5:20 A.M.; moon and stars shining; beyond York brief but intense snow; roads turn icy; with a dozen other cars unable to climb icy hill near Caledonia; delay here of one half hour (picture at left); over treacherous mountain roads to Turnpike at Breezewood; colder with high winds on Turnpike (picture at right); roads all ice vicinity Pittsburgh...

Across the Ohio River at East Liverpool (picture at left); reports from eastbound motorists that driving in northern Ohio (the worst in years; continue on Route 30 through Canton and Wooster; then northwest on Route 250 to Ashland and Norwalk; bye-pass Toledo; all snow and ice; into Michigan to Adrian, to Jackson; to motel (picture at right) two miles south of Lansing after midnight, after having been on the road for 19 hours straight, mostly through snow and ice. 593 miles this first day. Temperature at zero.

blocks.text: SECOND DAY – Thursday, December 13, 1951 - From Lansing through Grand Rapids to Muskegon (some sunshine) for noon meeting; return to Grand Rapids for meeting at 6:30 P.M. 148 miles second day.

At Muskegon, George Hansen, Norman Pickle,
Bill Eyke and Hal Ednburgh.

Driving through a blizzard in southern Mich-
igan as Gordon tries to get home.
In Grand Rapids we have rooms in Pantlind Hotel; view of the city from the hotel.

blocks.text: TRIP TO LOUISVILLE, KY. TO ATTEND THE MID-YEAR EXECUTIVE BOARD MEETING OF American Business Clubs. January 10 – 14, 1952. Gordon accompanied by Kit- ty. Total trip 1,394 miles.

FIRST DAY - Thursday, January 10, 1952; after returning from the Spring Twp. meeting next day in Reading, we pack our bags and with no sleep leave Lancaster with Benny Near, Kitty's nephew who accompanies us to Columbus. Departure time is 4:45 A. M. Rain is falling; in the hope of avoiding snow over the mountains we head south to Hagerstown and Route #40; then to Cumberland; but we encounter snow and bad driving conditions which necessitate a maximum speed of 30 mi. per hour for more than three hours. Finally reach Washington, Pa... and from here on make good time, still on Route #40 to Columbus, Ohio. 430 miles (including driving in city of Columbus). Dinner with Kitty's sister Helen and her family. Night with Dick and Charlotte Andes.

SECOND DAY – Friday, January 11, 1952; leave Columbus, Ohio at 8:50 A. M., to Xenia and Cincinnati; cross Ohio River into Kentucky and along Ohio River part way to Louisville. Warm, clear day. Arrive 3:30 P. M. 240 miles; Total Lancaster to Louisville 670 miles. Headquarters for meeting the Seelbach Hotel. With Board members and members of Louisville Chapter we go night-clubbing Friday night.
Gordon stands along the banks of the Ohio River, which we follow for many miles in Kentucky.
En route, we meet Second Vice-President W. L. A. Ewing and his wife, Kay. Here we have lunch together in Warsaw, Kentucky.

blocks.text: THIRD DAY — Saturday, January 12, 1952; entire day spent in Executive Board session at Seelbach Hotel, Gordon presiding. Louisville Chapter host at dinner-dance in the evening. To bed very late.
A clipping from the Louisville Courier-Journal....

FOURTH DAY - Sunday, January 13, 1952; after brunch at outskirts of Louisville, we manage to head for home at 1 P. M. through the Blue Grass section of Kentucky, to Frankfort, to Lexington, to Huntington, W. Va., to Charles-ton (275 miles); then on R#4 along the Elk River at night and in rain we fail to find a place to spend the night until we reach Sut-ton, W. Va. at 12:30 A. M. 366 miles.
Night spent at this comfortable cottage just north of Sutton, W. Va., after driving ninety one miles from Charleston at night, in rain.
The capitol of Kentucky at Frankfort on the way home. Rain is imminent. The capitol of Kentucktekyy aat Frannkfkfoort rain home. Rain is imminientent..
The weather has begun to clear as we head north-east through West Virginia to Buckhannon.

M.; to Buckhannon, to Elkins (at noon), to Mouth of Seneca, to Moore-field, to Romney, to Berkeley Springs, across Potomac River to Hancock, Md., and from here return same way back to Lancaster at 7:30 P. M. 358 miles; total trip home 724 miles. This final day clear and warm as a day in spring.
Bickle Knob, a few miles east of Elkins, is the second highest point in West Virginia.

A quick lunch at Harman, W. Va., in the heart of the mountains.

blocks.text: Berkeley Springs, W. Va., located six miles south of the Maryland line, is one of the oldest spas in the United States. Lord Fairfax in 1756 granted lands on which springs are located on condition they be forever free to the public. George Washington- ton frequently visited here.
A stop for refreshments as we approach Hagers-town, Md. The owner has his own special kind of humor painted on the walls .

We visit chapters in Charleston, Huntington,
Louisa, Dayton and Louisville, where the Dis-
trict Convention is held.
Kitty has her foot bandaged, the result of a broken blood vessel before we left home.
Through the Bluegrass Region... this stock farm near Paris, Ky. This farm section is among the finest in the country..
After recrossing the Ohio River at Pomeroy, Ohio, we drive in West Virginia as far as Ripley where we spend the night at this motel.

blocks.text: SECOND DAY: Saturday, June 14, 1952 - from Columbus to Dayton for mid-morning breakfast with Uncle Tom Evans, who is now employed at Wright Air Field; to Richmond, Ind., to Indianapolis, into Illinois as far as Tuscola. Heavy rains and intense heat.
Right - a roadside park in Indiana.

THIRD DAY: Sunday, June 15; FOURTH DAY: Monday, June 16; FIFTH DAY: Tuesday, June 17; SIXTH DAY: Wednesday, June 18, 1952.
Arrive in Springfield, Ill. Sunday noon after 75 mi. drive from Tuscola. We occupy the Gov- ernor's suite of two bedrooms and a parlor.
Meeting of the National Executive Board on Sunday afternoon.
National Convention sessions held on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, with Gordon presiding.
A variety of activities (see Convention program).
We experience some of the hottest weather for the month of June in the history of the state.
Headquarters for Convention: Hotel Leland.

blocks.text: SEVENTH DAY: Thursday, June 19, 1952 - Manage to get away from Springfield 2:00 P. M; southeast through Illinois into Indiana as far as Paoli for night. 234 miles. Heat still intense.
We discover the center of off population of the United States as fixed by the census of 1950 is a spot near Olney, Illinois.
Magnificent George Rogers Clark memorial at Vin-cennes, Ind., on the banks of the Wabash. Memorial commemorates Clark's capture of Ft. Sackville from the British in 1779.

Typical of much of Illinois is this scene show-
ing flat topography and roads with few turns.

blocks.text: EIGHTH DAY: Friday, June 20, 1952 – Paoli, Ind. to Louisville, Ky., to Bardstown and Danville; heading for mountains of North Carolina and Virginia, but decide to head for home due to discomfort of driving in severe heat; to Lexington and east through Kentucky; into West Virginia as far as Charleston at midnight.

In Bardstown, Ky. we visit Federal Hill, home of John Rowan, where in 1852 Stephen Foster, a relative of the Rowans, while on a visit, is said to have written "My Old Kentucky Home!" An ancient "darkly" strums a tune for the girls.
NINETH DAY: Saturday, June 21, 1952 - northeast through mountains of West Virginia to Elkins, visit Blackwater Falls State Park, land, Md., Hagerstown, and home before mid-night. .
Through the mountains of West Virginia. East of Elkins, we once again halted the car for a view of Bickle Knob.
